items.content_html:
Description

I typo in the code example demonstrating the interest in the polymorphic implementation of Promise[@@species].

Motivation

I've been coming to MDN to know what the standard is in JavaScript (which is more friendly than the official EcmaScript spec). I was also implementing a Promise from scratch before I tweaked it to my flavour... And my test case didn't match that code excerpt behaviour.

Additional details

N/A

Related issues and pull requests

N/A
items.title: fix: polymorphism code excerpt expectation

items.content_html: Correct me if I'm wrong, but I'm pretty sure that the handler.setPrototypeOf method is a trap for the internal method [[SetPrototypeOf]], not for Object.setPrototypeOf: https://262.ecma-international.org/13.0/#table-proxy-handler-methods
items.title: replace Object.setPrototypeOf with [[SetPrototypeOf]]

items.content_html:
When adding the Cascade Layer feature, the Web Platform also added a few CSSOM APIs.

I found it thanks to @dontcallmedom's mdn-gaps tool.

This PR only adds the extension for CSSImportRule. There are also two new interfaces that will be added in another PR (I want to be sure to have understood layers correctly by having this merged first.
items.title: Add CSSImportRule.layer document

items.content_html:
Description

Replace references to navigationStart with timeOrigin. Move discussion of "origin time" from Document.timeline to DocumentTimeline(). Specify the default originTime in DocumentTimline(). Add examples showing how originTime works. Define "non-active document".

Motivation

Clarity, completeness.

navigationStart is marked obsolete, doesn't match the terminology in the standard, and isn't terribly relevant to animation in any case.

The "origin time" discussion is redundant in Document.timeline because that timeline's origin time is always zero, and therefore not terribly observable.

"Origin time" and "time origin" are both confusing and easily confused (w3c/csswg-drafts#2079); hopefully examples help with that a bit.
items.title: Refactor `DocumentTimeline`'s discussion of time origin

items.content_html:
Description

Document that Element.animate() accepts a timeline option to associate the animation with a timeline other than document.timeline.

Motivation

Completeness. This option isn't useful now, but could become useful if scroll timelines are implemented.

Additional details

Spec reference.

Related issues and pull requests

Relates to mdn/browser-compat-data#18776, which would add browser compatibility data for this option.
items.title: Document `Element.animate()`'s `timeline` option

items.content_html:
To access webMidi you need to call requestMIDIAccess() in a secure context, the page permission policy must allow access, and the user must have granted access. The permission status can be queried using the permission API.

This PR is a test of how you might record the above information. I have added a "Security section" in both the Web MIDI API overview and in requestMIDIAccess(). I expect to remove one following this discussion.

My leaning is that security information should probably go in the requestMIDIAccess() - because that is where the access checks occur.

The permissions API behaviour is defined in the API spec so it makes sense to me that we should have a section in the API docs for this. We already have the concept of a security section that includes security requirements so perhaps this is the right place for this information too? That's kind of what I did.

But then I'm not sure the best place/way to show the compatibility information for the midi permission policy and permission API tokens (they don't have to be supported). For now I put these as additional compatibility information in the Web API overview.

Upshot, trying to work out where we should have security information and permission API status information.

@Elchi3 @wbamberg Any thoughts? I'm hoping for a pattern that can be reused next time I have to do one of these.
items.title: [TBD] WebMIDI security and permission API - how to capture?

items.content_html:
> **Note:** You have to remove this attribute entirely or set it to an empty string, `open=""` to hide details. `open="false"` makes the details visible because this attribute is Boolean.

Description

open="" is valid to hide details as an empty string is falsy.

Motivation

Just can be done without Element.removeAttribute("open")

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: `open=""` is valid to hide details

items.content_html:
Description

Move content of openOrClosedShadowRoot into dom namespace (according to suggestions in #23711)

  • redirect is added
  • a dom page is added as previously there's no such page
  • content in the openOrClosedShadowRoot is edited to reflect the description of the dom.openOrClosedShadowRoot method
  • add a note about Firefox's Element.openOrClosedShadowRoot

Motivation

Fix BCD and related issues for openOrClosedShadowRoot

Additional details

Content is based on

  • https://developer.chrome.com/docs/extensions/reference/dom/
  • https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/fe6e27d68a44c714dcce906749390378ede7d423

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #23711
items.title: move Web/API/Element/openOrClosedShadowRoot

items.content_html:
FF110 adds support for Navigator.getAutoplayPolicy(). This allows a developer to check whether a specific media element or audio context can autoplay. You can also check the general policy of whether they will autoplay.
This was needed because previously you had to start the element and check the play state to work out whether autoplay was blocked or not.

The bugzilla issue is https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1773551

Note that this is still in draft:

  • I am still waiting on confirmation of how parts of this works
  • Also have to update the "Autoplay guide for media and Web Audio APIs"

Other docs work can be tracked in #23676
items.title: Navigator.getAutoplayPolicy() docs

items.content_html:
Description

Annotate WebExtension API processId with "optional" and "deprecated" labels and explain that this attribute is no longer supported.

Motivation

This attribute existed in earlier versions of Chromium and was basically a leaky abstraction of Chromium multi-process architecture. It is no longer set on any objects created by the browser (returned by the APIs) and is ignored when user passes them to chromium APIs.

Additional details

In Chromium, it is possible to pass processId to webNavigation.getAllFrames() and webNavigation.getFrame() but it has no effect: it is ignored if it is a number and an error is thrown if it is incorrect type (not a number). Firefox never supported this attribute at all.

Related issues and pull requests

N/A
items.title: Update WebExtension API processId

items.content_html:
Description

Document the FormData constructor submitter parameter.

Also add a "Submit button" glossary page and link to it from various places to help facilitate a consistent and complete understanding of what a submit button is :)

Motivation

This is a new feature which should be landing in major browsers soon, so it would be useful to have it documented.

Additional details

Spec: https://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/#interface-formdata
Spec PR (merged): whatwg/xhr#366
Chromium implementation: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4189297
WebKit implementation (merged): WebKit/WebKit#9188
Gecko implementation: https://phabricator.services.mozilla.com/D167576

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #23917
items.title: Document the FormData constructor submitter parameter

items.content_html:
Description

This PR contains the reference documentation for the CSS Custom Highlight API.

Motivation

The API is now available in Chromium-based browser (Chrome 105+, Edge 105+, etc.), and is behind a flag in Safari.

Additional details

I wrote this blog post last year on css-tricks about it: https://css-tricks.com/css-custom-highlight-api-early-look/

The spec: https://www.w3.org/TR/css-highlight-api-1/

Related issues and pull requests

This fixes mdn/mdn#348

It is also related to this BCD PR (which should ideally land before): mdn/browser-compat-data#18720
items.title: Reference documentation for the CSS Custom highlight API

items.content_html:
Description

Address the confusion with CSS variable in #11382 with two examples.

The first example illustrates the point that var() can invoke variables defined in the later part of the same file.
The second example responds to the queries, specifically:

  • Does setting a custom property in one css file allow it's use in other cases files on the same page?
    • Answer: Yes
  • should the custom properties be defined in the first css file loaded?
    • Answer: Not necessarily

Motivation

Add helpful examples

Additional details

Some simple testing done around CSS var:

  • https://tlylt.github.io/web-examples/cssvar/index.html

Other docs:

  • https://blog.logrocket.com/css-variables-scoping/
  • https://css-tricks.com/a-complete-guide-to-custom-properties/#h-credit

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #11382
items.title: Add more examples to illustrate CSS var() usage
